settings.instructions:
Overview

This is the INL1Quiz for the Asymmetric Cryptography lecture. You must get 100% to pass the course. You can retake it. I recommend that you attempt it before the corresponding lecture and then retake it again afterwards.

Grading

If you fail, you will have to go study a bit more and complement your answers. There is a one hour cool-down between attempts. You must have 100% correct answers to pass. Questions will not give partial credit, you get either full score or none.

I suggest that you write down a short motivation for each answer, such that you can review them for the next attempt.

There is no deadline. (Well, the deadline is when you want to get the grade. When all INL1 assignments have a passing grade in Canvas, they'll be automatically transferred to LADOK. This is done once a week, then there might be a few days delay since one of us will have to see the email notification and go certify the results---i.e. click OK---manually in LADOK.)

entry.title: Key Exchange & Diffie-Hellman
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about the Diffie-Hellman key exchange protocol and its underlying problems.

choices.item_body: The Discrete Logarithm Problem (DLP) is: given g and g^x, find x.
The Diffie-Hellman Problem (DHP) is: given g, g^x, and g^y, find g^{xy}.
The Decisional Diffie-Hellman Problem (DDH) is: given g, g^x, g^y, and g^z, decide whether z = xy.
If we can solve DLP, then we can also solve DHP and DDH.
It has been proven that DHP cannot be solved without first solving DLP.
In Diffie-Hellman key exchange, Alice sends g^x to Bob, Bob sends g^y to Alice, and they both compute the shared secret g^{xy}.
An eavesdropper Eve who intercepts g^x and g^y can easily compute g^{xy} by multiplying them together.

entry.title: Diffie-Hellman Security
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about the security of unauthenticated Diffie-Hellman key exchange.

choices.item_body: Basic (unauthenticated) Diffie-Hellman is vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks.
In a man-in-the-middle attack on DH, Eve intercepts Alice's g^x, sends her own g^{x'} to Bob, intercepts Bob's g^y, and sends her own g^{y'} to Alice.
After a successful man-in-the-middle attack, Eve shares one key with Alice and a different key with Bob, allowing her to decrypt and re-encrypt all messages.
The man-in-the-middle attack works because Alice cannot tell whether g^y came from Bob or from Eve.
To prevent man-in-the-middle attacks, the values g^x and g^y must be authenticated (e.g., using digital signatures).
The DHP assumption alone is sufficient to guarantee secure key exchange in practice.

entry.title: ElGamal Encryption
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about the ElGamal encryption scheme.

choices.item_body: In ElGamal, the public key consists of (g, g^x) and the private key is x.
To encrypt a message m, the sender chooses a random y and computes the ciphertext (g^y, m * (g^x)^y).
ElGamal encryption is deterministic: encrypting the same message twice with the same public key always produces the same ciphertext.
The random value y used during encryption must be different for each encryption to ensure semantic security.
ElGamal's semantic security relies on the DDH assumption.
The receiver can decrypt because they know x and can compute (g^y)^{-x} to recover m.

entry.title: Security Notions
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about security notions for public-key encryption.

choices.item_body: Semantic security means an adversary cannot derive any meaningful information about the plaintext from the ciphertext.
In a chosen plaintext attack (CPA), the adversary can choose plaintexts and obtain their encryptions.
CPA is particularly relevant for public-key encryption because anyone can encrypt using the public key.
In the IND-CPA game, the adversary submits two messages and must guess which one was encrypted in the challenge ciphertext.
IND-CCA2 (adaptive chosen ciphertext attack) allows the adversary to query a decryption oracle even after receiving the challenge ciphertext (but not on the challenge itself).
IND-CPA security is stronger than IND-CCA2 security.

entry.title: Digital Signatures
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about digital signatures.

choices.item_body: Digital signatures use the private key for signing and the public key for verification.
Digital signatures provide non-repudiation: the signer cannot deny having signed a message.
Anyone with the signer's public key can verify a signature, making signatures publicly verifiable.
The ElGamal signature scheme uses a collision-resistant hash function to prevent forgery attacks.
Without the hash function in ElGamal signatures, an attacker could create valid signatures for new messages by combining existing signatures (due to the homomorphic property).
Digital signatures and MACs provide identical security properties since both verify message authenticity.

entry.title: Homomorphic Properties
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about homomorphic properties in cryptography.

choices.item_body: A homomorphism is a map that preserves structure between two algebraic structures.
ElGamal encryption has a multiplicative homomorphism: multiplying two ciphertexts gives a valid encryption of the product of the plaintexts.
If you multiply two ElGamal ciphertexts (g^y, m*g^{xy}) and (g^{y'}, m'*g^{xy'}), you get a ciphertext that decrypts to m*m'.
Homomorphic properties are always desirable in encryption schemes.
Homomorphic properties are particularly dangerous for signature schemes because they allow forging signatures on new messages.
Padding schemes like OAEP can be used to counter homomorphic attacks on public-key encryption.
Fully homomorphic encryption allows arbitrary computations on encrypted data without decryption.

entry.title: PKI & Certificate Validation
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) and certificate validation.

choices.item_body: When validating a certificate, you must verify the signature chain up to a trusted root CA.
Verifying only the signature on a certificate is sufficient to trust it.
Certificate validation must include checking the validity interval (not-before / not-after dates).
A Certificate Revocation List (CRL) is a CA-signed list of certificate serial numbers that should be rejected.
OCSP (Online Certificate Status Protocol) allows real-time checking of whether a specific certificate has been revoked.
Once a certificate's signature is verified, there is no need to check for revocation.
Certificate revocation checking is important because a CA may need to invalidate a certificate before its expiration (e.g., if the private key is compromised).

entry.title: Symmetric Key Distribution
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about symmetric key distribution and Kerberos.

choices.item_body: A Key Distribution Centre (KDC) is a central entity that helps distribute session keys to parties who share permanent keys with the KDC.
A session key is a temporary key used for a specific communication session.
A permanent key is used to securely distribute session keys.
In Kerberos, Alice and Bob can establish a shared session key even if they have never communicated before, as long as they both share keys with the KDC.
Kerberos uses public-key cryptography to distribute session keys.
In Kerberos, a ticket encrypted under Bob's key allows Alice to prove to Bob that the KDC authorized her session key.
Kerberos tickets include timestamps and lifetimes to prevent replay attacks.

entry.title: Asymmetric vs Symmetric Cryptography
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about the comparison between asymmetric and symmetric cryptography.

choices.item_body: Public-key cryptography solves the key distribution problem by allowing parties to establish shared secrets without prior secure communication.
Asymmetric encryption is generally slower than symmetric encryption.
In practice, public-key cryptography is often used to exchange symmetric keys, which are then used for bulk encryption.
AES (a symmetric cipher) can achieve semantic security when used with a proper mode of operation that includes a random IV.
Symmetric ciphers require that the IV (initialization vector) be kept secret.
Both ElGamal encryption and AES (with CBC/CTR mode) achieve semantic security through the use of randomness in each encryption.
